title: 113_s1763
content: The Act may be cited as the "Child Support Enforcement Effectiveness Act of 2013" and establishes a Commission on Child Support. The Commission on Child Support is established with 15 members appointed by various leaders in the government and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Commission on Child Support, established with 15 members appointed by various leaders, will have 7 members appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Members must be knowledgeable on child support issues, including representation for noncustodial parents. The appointment and quorum procedures will follow the Family Support Act of 1988. The Commission on Child Support, with 15 members appointed by various leaders, will hold meetings open to the public. The first meeting will be scheduled when all members are available, and a chairman will be elected during this meeting. Subsequent meetings will be called by the chairman or by majority vote. The Commission on Child Support allows interested persons to present statements at open meetings, with public notice provided beforehand. Members do not receive compensation but may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission's duties include evaluating the effectiveness of child support enforcement programs. The Commission on Child Support will evaluate existing child support enforcement programs and collection practices, hold national conferences on child support reform, and submit a report to Congress with recommendations by October 1, 2015. The Commission on Child Support will take administrative actions to improve child support enforcement, including enhancing program effectiveness, ensuring children benefit from support payments, promoting parental engagement, and considering parental time and visitation in determining child support. Alternative dispute resolution may also play a role in these determinations. The Commission on Child Support aims to enhance program effectiveness, promote parental engagement, and consider parental time in determining child support. They are developing best practices for connecting custodial parents to services, supporting employment for both custodial and noncustodial parents, and establishing services for noncustodial parents to track child support payments and address uncollectible arrearages. Options are being developed for states to collect child support payments from individuals who owe. The Commission on Child Support is working on best practices to connect custodial parents to services, support employment for both parents, and establish services for tracking child support payments. They are also developing options for states to collect child support payments from individuals with arrearages exceeding $2,500. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting a report, with $2,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2014-2015 for funding. Any unobligated funds at the termination of the Commission will be returned to the Treasury of the United States. Section 455(a)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to reinstate federal matching of state spending on child support incentive payments, effective as of October 1, 2013.
